results.title: The Four Minute Mile
results.brief_description: An on-the-spot account of Roger Bannister’s record-breaking mile, run on the Oxford University Athletic Ground. Shows the brilliant performance of Chataway and Brasher as pace-makers. The film concludes with a brief camera interview with Bannister

results.title: The Four day week
results.creator_credit: Isaac Kleinerman, Gordon Hyatt and CBS News
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “21st Century”.
Discusses some issues related to work in the future-30 hour week, automatic unionism, early retirement. Also looks at some of the consequences of these ideas, especially the use of leisure and recreation facilities. Reported by Walter Cronkite.

results.title: The Fountain of Jabalia
results.creator_credit: Jose Quisand and United Nations Films
results.brief_description: Depicts the life of Palesinian Arab refugees at Jabalia Camp, in the Gaza Strip. The film shows the work of the vocational training schools which are producing skilled craftsmen whose services are in keen demand. It also illistrates how the United Nations is setting up families in their own farms so that they can become self supporting.

results.title: The Foundations of wealth. Part 1. How it all began
results.brief_description: Uses animation and docuemtary footage to establish the concept of living at subsistence level. Shows how vulnerable people are when they need to consume everything they produce in order to survive and points towards the concept of creating a surplus. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: The Fortune in the forests
results.brief_description: Portrays the Swedish lumber industry, which in the 1950’s played a vital part in Sweden’s economy. Near the end of winter, power saws fell thousands of trees. The logs are hauled by tractor to the nearest river bank. In spring the logs are bulldozed into the melting rivers, and commence their journey in the fast flowing waters to the timbermills which cluster around the river mouths. Here they are sorted and graded by skilled lumberjacks, hauled into mills, and cut into timber for an endless variety of uses. In Sweden trees are a crop, and care is taken to prevent bushfires and indiscriminate felling. The forests of Sweden are a heritage from the past-they must be replanted and guarded from danger so that they may continue to be a source of wealth to future generations. Story by Albert Viksen; photographed by Sven Olsson; narrated by Burnett Anderson.

results.title: The Forgotten indians
results.creator_credit: Anthony de Lotbinière and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World Is Ours”.
A study of the work of the Andean Indian Mission of the United Nations in the Peruvian highlands showing how education, agricultural methods and living standards are being improved. Commentary written by Paul Rotha and narrated by Colin Wills.

results.title: The Forgotten genocide
results.creator_credit: Atlantis Productions and J. Michael Hagopian
results.brief_description: An account of the genocide of the Armenians by the Turks in 1915. Includes eyewitness accounts and archival film footage. Places the events in the context of Armenian history and culture. Narrated by Mike Connors.

results.title: The Forgiving Lord
results.creator_credit: Vincenzo Labella, Franco Zeffirelli and Don Bosco Multimedia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Jesus of Nazareth”.
The continuing story of the life of Jesus Christ from: Jesus cures the paralytic man; Jesus is welcomed by Matthew and tells the parable of the prodigal son; Peter and Matthew are reconciled; Matthew and Peter leave everything and follow Jesus.

results.title: The Forerunner
results.creator_credit: Shell Film Unit and John Heyer
results.brief_description: Professor C.H. Munro introduces Australia’s water problem - the periodic cycles of flood and drought and the first major step in its solution, the Snowy Mountains scheme. The first part shows floods in town and country areas and rescue teams at work; the second, drought and a family forced to abandon their property; finally, the aims of the Snowy Mountains Scheme and some of the work in progress. Little commentary is used. Ballads and natural sound accompany evocative visuals.
